                 Display conventions
                 Individual elements of the sentences are displayed in a special form. The
                 meanings are:

                 Italics                  marks character strings describing the software
                                          elements, e.g. the Buckets dialog.

                 Bold                     marks character strings to be entered via keyboard, e.g.:
                                          Enter 0.

                 >                        shows the way to open a dialog, e.g. Display > Filler
                                          orders > Context menu - List > Order overview.

                 []                       square brackets mark the buttons in the dialog, e. g.
                                          [OK] to save the data.

                 <>                       pointed brackets refer to keys or shortcuts on the
                                          keyboard, e. g. <F1> is used to open the online help

A+W Production Overview                                                                                                                     A-21
Overview                                                                                  Tutorial




           Overview
           The training on A+W Production is aimed at producers of IG, toughened, and
           laminated glass as well as processors who want to get an overview of the per-
           formance and the processes of A+W Production.
           This system overview shall give you a general idea of the performance and the
           possibilities of A+W Production. All subjects and modules will be treated in
           closer detail in separate training sessions and tutorials.
           A thorough understanding of the system architecture and the modular struc-
           ture of A+W Production are prerequisite for the handling and operation of the
           individual areas and the gathering of the necessary knowledge.

           Sets of Topics
           This tutorial offers the following sets of topics:
           •   A+W Production introduces itself
           •   Basic Module A+W Production
           •   Supplements A+W Production

               Required knowledge
               Basic knowledge of EDP or Windows are prerequisite for using A+W Pro-
               duction.


           Tutorial Structure

                      A+W Production introduces
                      itself
                      Ever-increasing production requirements call for more and more powerful con-
                      trol and scheduling systems.
                      A+W Production is the production planning and control system of A+W Soft-
                      ware GmbH. The modular architecture allows tailoring it to your requirements
                      in an optimum way. Which of the offered solutions will suit your company's
                      needs best, will be analyzed in detailed discussions.
                      A+W Production offers a multitude of state-of-the-art methods and tools for
                      planning, controlling, monitoring, and analyzing your entire production - from
                      order entry up to NC code creation and the booking of barcode data. In addi-
                      tion to these standardized processes the system allows the direct and dynamic
                      intervention into the production process, e.g. in order to add important, urgent
                      orders or to remove bottlenecks. This gives you full control over all production-
                      relevant resources and data at all times - machinery, costs, times, and capac-
                      ities.
                      A high degree of quality is achieved by the networking of machinery and other
                      A+W Software GmbH software modules and due to process visualization and
                      control by means of production terminals at the individual workstations.
                      At present, the software is being run world-wide, in 12 languages.
                      To handle the modular structure of A+W Production, the software has been di-

                      •   Basic system

                        During the scheduling process, the following steps are performed for every or-

                        1 What? - Master data

                      Batch Creation
                      Batches can be created in the following views:
                      •   Order view
                      •   Batch view
                      •   Filler order view
                      •   Detailed view
                      •   Processing view
                      •   Glass type view

                      Batch creation
                      The planning process usually consists of different steps. Products are first
                      grouped by main criteria, after which the result is checked: Quantity, yield, res-
                      idue plates, stock sizes, number of racks required. The elements are now
                      grouped into different batches, or elements are added to a batch to improve
                      the results.
                      Batches can be created according to the following criteria for example:
                      By glass type: Thick lites usually are usually bigger and are more expensive
                      and heavier. They are therefore often produced in separate batches.
                      By product type: In complex productions, different glass types (e. g. IG, tough-
                      ened, and laminated glass) are often separated and take different paths



A-38                                                                       A+W Production Overview
Tutorial                                                               Basic Module A+W Production




                      through production. Even at the production scheduling stage you actively de-
                      cide about sequence, production path, and yield.
                      By processing step: Certain processing steps require quite a long lead time or
                      are so expensive that the yield is quite secondary (e. g. screen printing or coat-
                      ing). In this case, the batches are created in the processing view based on the
                      corresponding processing criteria.
                      By production date: Capacity planning determines the production date for the
                      corresponding processing step. That is your main scheduling criteria in this
                      case.
                      By order or item: The program traces the production progress of every ele-
                      ment. You can create different batches for different order items and even ele-
                      ments. This is especially useful for complex productions. An order can also
                      include different product types, and orders can be distributed to several batch-
                      es. The advantage of this method is that right to the last, you can keep ele-
                      ments of your order open for changes. You can start production even if one of
                      the items is causing difficulties at order processing. Alternatively, the program
                      can be configured to show only complete orders in the order view. This pro-
                      vides less flexibility but makes the process easier. Instead of leaving the solu-
                      tion of this problem to the system you can solve it already at order processing
                      by defining guidelines, e. g. regarding the products that are to be added to an
                      order, and those that have to be separated.

                      General rules
                      A batch must make sense: It should have a suitable size (approx. 2 working
                      hours). It should be possible to adapt its size to improve the result. Special
                      products should not be isolated (mix them with the standard batches and put
                      them onto separate racks).
                      A batch creation strategy is good if it works for your purposes.
                      Of course there are exceptions: Sometimes, even the optimum batch is not
                      good enough. You should therefore try to spend not too much time on this but
                      should rather concentrate on getting your production going.

                      Detailed Scheduling
                      This subject area will introduce detailed scheduling.

                      Objectives

                      • Knowing the targets and general conditions of detailed scheduling
                      • Knowing about the different optimization modes
                      • Knowing about the different organization types


                      Benefit

                      Detailed scheduling includes various modules and functions which shall help you
                      adjust your production with regard to production sequence and cutting optimization.
                      Detailed scheduling begins where rough scheduling ends. The task of detailed
                      scheduling is to determine the best production sequence for the contents of the
                      batches.


                      Definitions

                      Groups                      Groups are formed by individual, characteristic
                                                  properties such as customer number or glass type.

                      Sorting                     Sorting is done by properties which have a consecutive
                                                  value in the defined group (e. g. glass thickness or
                                                  size).

                      Physical rack               Rack (A rack, L rack, fixed rack)

                      Logical rack                Several logical racks (stacks of glass) can exist on the
                                                  same physical rack.

                      Organization                Production organization with regard to sequence and
                                                  production processes by means of rules and filters.


                      Note

                      Separation of glass types   makes sure that different glass types will not be mixed
                                                  in a stack; each glass type is put onto a separate stack
                                                  on a physical or logical rack.




A-40                                                                         A+W Production Overview
Tutorial                                                                   Basic Module A+W Production




                      Detailed Scheduling in General
                      A product's way on the shop floor can include different processing steps.
                      The processing time depends on the individual process. A main factor is the
                      space available on the shop floor, which also influences detailed scheduling.
                      If there is only little space after the cutting table, e.g. for sorting the lites, this
                      situation must be compensated by the appropriate sequence of lites.
                      For assembly on the IG line, the lites of a unit have to be put side by side but
                      not necessarily on the same rack. This means that depending on the optimi-
                      zation, sorting may have to take place before the line.




                          Optimization result
                          Optimizing lites with as little waste as possible does not always have to be
                          the main target of detailed scheduling. This is the case for instance if such
                          an optimization results in an unreasonable amount of sorting work before
                          assembly.


                      The Process of Detailed Scheduling
                      Detailed scheduling is the second step of production scheduling and starts
                      when rough scheduling is finished. The task of detailed scheduling is deter-
                      mining the production sequence for the elements included in the batches in or-
                      der to define the racks (quantity and allocation).
                      The production sequence can be determined by criteria like:
                      •   Customer's requirements (e. g. unloading sequence at delivery),
                      •   the results of rack and packing optimization (Rack Optimizer) or
                      •   production restrictions
                      Detailed scheduling consists of various steps. All necessary processes are
                      handled in the background:

                      •   As a next step, detailed scheduling deals with putting the lites onto racks.

                      Rack and Stack Logic
                      Detailed scheduling offers various criteria for setting lites onto racks. You can
                      put complete groups onto a rack, split groups, etc.
                      The available detailed scheduling tools and methods allow adjusting your pro-
                      duction flexibly to the results of optimization (see illustration). Not only do you
                      optimize the production sequence but implement a simple and efficient rack
                      and stack logic. The system always stays in control of the production paths
                      and processing sequences which makes the handling of units (IG, laminated
                      glass) much more efficient.
                      This improves the cycle times and avoid unnecessary resorting, breakage,
                      and searching for lites.

                      •   Special A rack organizations
                      •   Special harp rack organizations

                      Organization Types
                      So-called Organizations are used for correct and efficient batch planning. An
                      organization is just a set of rules to handle production. Depending on the com-
                      pany's structure, any number of organizations (toughened glass organization,
                      IG organization, processing organization, etc.) can be defined. The individual
                      organizations organize the racks for the production steps (IG line, furnace,
                      etc.).


                      Additional information
                       Detailed Scheduling: Tutorial, “Organizations” on page D-316
                       Detailed Scheduling: Software Reference, “Organization” on page D-379


                      Organization Type and Batch Type
                      Each element and processing has its own element type or processing type
                      (basic glass, toughened glass, etc.), and its supply type (ordered, cutting,
                      etc.). Depending on these two properties, the element or processing is allocat-
                      ed to a certain batch type. This way, elements with different processing types
                      can be allocated to the same batch type, to be treated together, e.g. at rack
                      allocation.
                      Apart from that, each organization has a certain organization type which de-
                      fines the elements to be allocated to the organization. Ideally, definition and
                      filters are based on differences and similarities:
                      •   Shapes?, Rectangles?
                      •   Height?, Weight?
                      •   …
                      Production batches are created at cutting for different element types and dif-
                      ferent glass types.

                      Machinery Allocation
                      This session introduces the subject of machinery allocation.

                      Objectives

                      • Knowing about machinery allocation


                      Benefit

                      Machines represent the physical machinery. Machines are therefore the basis for
                      production control.


                      Definitions

                      Machinery                   Machines represent the physical machinery.

                      Logical machine             A logical machine is a technological description of a
                                                  machine part or of a machine's operating status. A fur-
                                                  nace for instance can be used for Toughening and
                                                  Annealing. The logical machine therefore serves to distin-
                                                  guish the two processes (since the physical machine can-
                                                  not perform both processes at the same time) and is thus
                                                  also the basis for correct processing times, cost calcula-
                                                  tion, and statistical analysis.

                      Machine types               The machine types are predefined and are allocated to
                                                  the machines. The machine types define the type of
                                                  machine, e. g. Cutting, Spacer bender, or Others.

                      Work processes              Work processes connect the properties of the processing
                                                  type e. g. Cutting and the properties of the workpiece.
                                                  They are based on processing types or articles.

                      Processing types            Processing types describe the technical type of process-
                                                  ing.

                      Processing article          Processing articles define - in closer detail than the pro-
                                                  cessing type - the technical type of processing.


                      Note

                      Allocation of work processesWork process allocation allows the user to intervene in
                                                  the production process. Work process allocation links
                                                  logical machines and work processes.

                      Priorities                  Work process allocation serves to define the priorities of
                                                  logical machines. You therefore define that the specified
                                                  work process shall be performed on the optimal machine,
                                                  as cost-effective as possible.

                      Allocation of work processes
                      This is where logical machines are allocated to work processes. The se-
                      quence, and thus the priority of the logical machines, can be individually de-
                      fined for every work process. You therefore define the priorities of machines
                      in the production process.
                      Work processes tend to be allocated to machines that can perform several
                      functions like the CNC centre for instance, rather than being allocated to more
                      specialized machines which can perform just one function.
                      As a result, more work processes are allocated to the expensive CNC centre
                      which will cause a bottleneck sooner or later.
                      This can be prevented by defining priorities in the allocation of work process-
                      es, and by defining flexibly adaptable work processes.
                      Define work processes which exactly reflect the individual applications, and al-
                      locate these work processes to suitable logical machines. This makes sure
                      that the work processes will be performed by the most cost-effective machine.


                         Example: Work process allocation
                         You have got a rectangular grinding machine and a CNC centre on your shop
                         floor. Both can execute the processing step Grinding.
                         • The list of work processes includes the work process Rectangular grinding
                           which is used for all rectangular lites. In work process allocation, the work
                           process Rectangular grinding is allocated to the Rectangular grinder. It
                           has got top priority.
                         • The list of work processes includes the work process Shape grinding
                           which is used for all shapes. In work process allocation, the work process
                           Shape grinding is allocated to the CNC centre.
                         • The CNC centre is also allocated to the work process Rectangular
                           grinding, albeit with a lower priority.
                         With these settings, rectangular lites will be ground by the more cost-effective
                         rectangular grinder. In case of a bottleneck, rectangular lites will also be
                         ground by the CNC centre.


                      Additional information
                       Machinery Allocation: Tutorial, “Allocation of Work Processes” on page G-808
                       Machinery Allocation: Software Reference, “Work Process” on page G-868

                      Capacity Planning
                      Objectives

                      • Knowing about capacity planning.
                      • Knowing about operating principles and options .
                      • Knowing about the process flow and the interaction with other modules.


                      Benefit

                      Capacity planning allows providing your customers with quick information regarding
                      general possibilities, use of production capacities, and costs.


                      Definitions

                      Transition times            Certain work processes require an additional rest for
                                                  the glass, e. g. 8 hours for the autoclave process. This
                                                  means that a transition time is necessary between two
                                                  work processes.

                      Capacity                    Defines the time for which a machine is available for
                                                  production (e. g. 1 shift = 8 hours).

                      Use of capacity             Time span in the total capacity for which work has been
                                                  scheduled on the machine (e. g. 50% - 4 hours of a
                                                  total capacity of 8 hours in shift 1).

                      Reservation                 Time reserved for special orders (e. g. for a special
                                                  customer or special glass types). Reservations can be
                                                  defined as individual reservations for a certain shift or
                                                  as series (e. g. 2 hours of a total capacity of 8 hours in
                                                  shift 1 is reserved for customer.08 on machine 15).

                      Campaign                    Time span in the total capacity of a shift in which the
                                                  machine performs just a single type of work process
                                                  (e. g. every Thursday shift 1 - screen printing, colour:
                                                  blue).

                      Machine                     Physical machine defined in machinery allocation.


                      Note

                      Mode                        If production dates are calculated based on the delivery
                                                  date (backdating) and the system realizes that the start
                                                  of production lies in the past or that the delivery date
                                                  cannot be kept, the system switches to the express
                                                  schedule. Capacity planning recalculates the
                                                  production dates in this case.

                      Production monitor          This can be used for direct editing of the corresponding
                                                  machine and its settings (e. g. capacities) and the
                                                  scheduled orders.

                      A+W Capacity Planner
                      A+W Capacity Planner serves to schedule the existing production capacities,
                      directly balancing them against the capacities already reserved for the orders
                      on hand.
                      This permits to detect bottlenecks early on, and to amend the planning results
                      where necessary. The desired delivery date is also checked as well as the pro-
                      duction costs incurred under the defined general conditions. All information
                      (delivery date confirmed / cannot be kept, costs and individual production
                      dates) are reported to the ERP system.
                      Scheduling is based on the use of capacity by machine or working area, com-
                      pared with the existing capacities. This is based on the capacity planning mas-
                      ter data defined for the individual machines in the shape of times, shift or work
                      plans, and the allocated costs per machine and work process.
                      The production costs for alternative production options can be shown if re-
                      quired, compared with the selected machine and work process. The produc-
                      tion planning system takes the defined use of production machinery into
                      account, based on the organizational rules in detailed scheduling.
                      Detailed analyses can be run by area or machine, and even by order item. A
                      central production monitor helps to control the use of capacity. This allows
                      quick intervention should capacities be exceeded.
                      The A+W Capacity Planner distinguishes common and express schedules.
                      The common schedule offers longer transition times. If capacity planning
                      comes up with production dates which lie in the past or if the delivery date can-
                      not be kept in view of the existing capacities, capacity planning automatically
                      switches to express schedule for rescheduling.

                      Production monitor
                      The production monitor provides you with a detailed capacity overview. The
                      displayed data can be edited right away, e. g. to lock shifts or define bottleneck
                      machines. The figures show if and which machines are overloaded so that you
                      can reschedule capacities accordingly.
                      Campaigns will of course be considered for rescheduling.




                      The production monitor uses icons and colours for conveying certain informa-
                      tion:
                      •   Backlog (red, yellow, or green dots left from the machine name).
                      •   Shift (grey bar on a calendar day).
                      •   Use of capacity (green bar on a shift).
                      •   Overload (percentage for a shift).
                      •   Work progress (blue bar covering the green shift capacity bar in the course
                          of the day).
                      •   Reservations (hatched area in a shift).
                      There are two more symbols for shifts, X and !. X means that the shift is locked.
                      ! means that the shift is locked except for rush orders (e. g. due to repair work)-
                      .

                      Optimization systems
                      A+W Software GmbH optimization system serve to optimize processes and
                      yield in an optimal way. Used at different points of production, they have differ-
                      ent tasks.

                      Objectives

                      • Knowing and understanding the different optimization systems.
                      • Finding the optimization systems which suit your business requirements.


                      Benefit

                      Optimization systems help you to use your production capacities to the best effect,
                      and minimize the waste. This saves time and money.


                      Definitions

                      A+W Realtime Optimizer      Online cutting control station which allows manipulating
                                                  the batches after optimization.

                      A+W Sequence Optimizer      Optimizes the waste of individual glass types taking
                                                  into account the sorting sequence. Sequence Optimizer
                                                  is the core of the PPS A+W Production but is also
                                                  available as a stand-alone production system for
                                                  optimization and control purposes.

                      A+W Shape Optimizer         Arranges shapes from different items within a
                                                  rectangle, saving space.

                      A+W Rack Optimizer          Permits the direct packing of lites onto transport racks
                                                  right on the shop floor, and optimizes the loading of lites
                                                  onto racks, and the racks themselves (weight, load,
                                                  loading sequence).

                      A+W DynOpt                  Dynamic optimization and cutting control system which
                                                  achieves the optimum yield while sticking to the defined
                                                  production sequences (using a sorting system, e.g.
                                                  Hegla Sortjet).

                      A+W Furnace Optimizer       Determines the optimal furnace bed load based on the
                                                  defined conditions.


                      Note

                      The use                     Using the right optimization system mainly depends on
                                                  the general conditions and the targets - is yield
                                                  important or the sequence, or both? Which machines
                                                  will be controlled? What are the paths through
                                                  production?

                      Realtime Optimizer
                      A+W Realtime Optimizer is a control station for improving the yield and the cut-
                      ting processes.
                      The system allows the automatic linking of identical glass types from different
                      batches. This helps to avoid residue plates; breakage can be cut again right
                      away to be loaded together with the original item, or separately.
                      This extension is available only in connection with A+W Production.
                      The program supports these fundamental ideas with the following features:
                      •   It controls cutting by means of optimized detailed scheduling data.
                      •   Rush orders, breakage or filler sizes can be automatically re-optimized in
                          a residue plate.
                      •   Cutting tables are controlled online by means of communication logs sup-
                          ported by the table manufacturers.
                      •   Manually entered lites, breakage and fillers are optimized directly at the
                          cutting table.
                      •   Optimizations existing in A+W Production can be checked for table optimi-
                          zation, they can be broken down, rearranged, and optimized again. You
                          can flexibly and quickly react to the situation in the cutting area.
                      •   By adding breakage, filler sizes and rush orders, bigger optimizations can
                          be created. Defined sequences on A racks are maintained.
                      •   A+W Production Even at the detailed scheduling stage, ALCIM allows to
                          optimize cutting of every batch on the scheduled cutting table.
                      •   Realtime Optimizer is specially configured for a cutting table and can trans-
                          fer the batches scheduled and optimized for this cutting table, including the
                          cutting code.
                      •   When the required machinery code has been transferred to the cutting tale,
                          the breakout pattern can be directly displayed on a terminal.




A-64                                                                      A+W Production Overview
Tutorial                                                                Supplements A+W Production




                      Cutting table optimizations
                      Cutting table optimizations are created by Realtime Optimizer right at the cut-
                      ting table. Upstream systems supply complete optimizations which can be bro-
                      ken down and rearranged by Realtime Optimizer. You can combine any
                      number of jobs, provided there is enough space for the racks at the cutting ta-
                      ble.
                      When you create local optimizations, you can take into account residue plates
                      on the cutting table, use different stockplates, or use a residue stock. Break-
                      age, rush or filler orders can be excluded or integrated as required.
                      Cutting table optimizations are saved in the database and are used for cutting
                      if required.

                      Cutting table control
                      Realtime Optimizer serves as a control unit for a cutting table.
                      A cutting code is created and transferred to the cutting table, or is made avail-
                      able in a defined directory. Depending on the cutting table and the technical
                      solution to control it, the cutting code is transferred to the table by another ta-
                      ble, or loaded from the manufacturer's software from the defined directory.
                      When the cutting code for a stockplate has been sent to the table, Realtime
                      Optimizer considers the stockplate as completed. If transfer of the cutting code
                      is interrupted, work can be resumed at this precise spot.

                      Master data
                      If the access to master data has been configured, these can be displayed and
                      adapted right at the cutting table.
                      Master data include:
                      •   Article
                      •   Glass types
                      •   Tables
                      •   Optimization parameters
                      •   Stockplates
                      These master data and how to use them are described in section Detailed
                      scheduling in the A+W Production user manual.
                      Please note that the master data must be identical throughout the company.
                      In case of questions please always contact a member of the A+W team.


                      Additional information
                       Realtime Optimizer: Tutorial, “Realtime Optimizer” on page J-1105

                      Sequence Optimizer
                      A+W Sequence Optimizer optimizes the yield of the individual glass types in
                      the scheduled batches, taking into account the sorting sequence, express li-
                      tes, and filler items as well as all known shapes and free shapes.
                      It allows optimizing individual lites and calculates the optimization result per
                      glass type and batch. The loading of lites onto A racks or harp racks in produc-
                      tion sequence is also taken into account.
                      This way, a good yield can be achieved in a very short time. This results in con-
                      siderable material savings and thus much lower costs. Sequence Optimizer
                      can be configured to meet individual requirements. The graphic display of the
                      result allows the quick and easy processing of patterns.




                      Another extension level also offers a sequenced optimization. It helps to min-
                      imize manual sorting by synchronizing the lites of an IG unit; this works with a
                      limited number of different glass types per batch.




A-66                                                                      A+W Production Overview
Tutorial                                                               Supplements A+W Production




                      Shape Optimizer
                      A+W Shape Optimizer allows to run an extended shape optimization to im-
                      prove the yield.
                      By linking the shape contours, the system determines the breakable combina-
                      tion of two shapes and creates the necessary auxiliary cuts.




                      Due to the ever increasing complexity of the geometry of windows, shop
                      fronts, and interior designs, the number of shapes is on a constant up in the
                      product mixture.
                      Common cutting optimizations are usually based on the rectangle surrounding
                      the shape. Especially for triangular shapes, this results in a very poor yield be-
                      cause up to 50 % of the rectangle can be waste.
                      The A+W module Shape Optimizer remedies this by nesting (arranging)
                      shapes from different items within the rectangle, saving valuable space.
                      To keep the necessary work at the cutting table to a minimum, maximally two
                      shapes are nested within a rectangle. A+W Shape Optimizer takes into ac-
                      count any possibly necessary auxiliary cuts to make sure that the shapes can
                      be removed from the surrounding rectangle without problems.

Supplements A+W Production                                                                    Tutorial




                      Rack Optimizer
                      A+W Rack Optimizer allows the direct loading of lites onto transport racks on
                      the shop floor. The 3D rack view at the A+W Production Terminal shows the
                      workers the required packing sequence.
                      The task of this module is to distribute the required order items to racks and
                      boxes - taking into account the defined conditions - so that a minimum of trans-
                      port space is needed, and customer requirements are met with regard to the
                      rack load. The planning strategy is defined by packing rules. Apart from infor-
                      mation on the physical properties such as height, width, and weight, these in-
                      clude customized parameters for the racks to be used such as the number of
                      stacks that can be loaded next to or on top of each other.
                      This rack optimization influences the whole production process - starting from
                      optimization and cutting, the sequence of lites and units is passed on accord-
                      ing to the rack allocation in Rack Optimizer.
                      At its highest configuration level, A+W Rack Optimizer is already integrated in
                      A+W Enterprise through specific rules and queries which even permits rack-
                      oriented order entry / purchasing which is passed on to the shop floor.
                      This completely integrated A+W system optimizes and aligns two things - the
                      sequence of lites and units based on the sequence of racks and the rack itself
                      (weight of the lites, space, risk of breakage, unloading sequence, ...). The
                      rules can be defined in the organizational meeting by the customer and A+W.

                      DynOpt
                      A+W DynOpt is a dynamic optimization and cutting control system for cutting,
                      breakout, and sorting. As an extension of A+W Production, it provides opti-
                      mum yield while keeping the defined production sequence and controls dy-
                      namic sorting systems like HEGLA SortJet and BYSTRONIC first’sort.
                      DynOpt permits to control several cutting tables and IG lines at the same time.
                      While cutting you can dynamically switch to another cutting table. The module
                      also takes into account the different cutting performance of two tables (e. g.
                      float and laminated glass).
                      Breakage is swiftly recut so that units can already be completed in the buffer.
                      The system controls and synchronizes several cutting tables, sorting buffers
                      and residue management systems and ensures the real-time data exchange
                      with other production systems, for example IG lines. In connection with a dy-
                      namically controlled interim buffer (HEGLA SortJet, BYSTRONIC first’sort), a
                      constant flow of glass is achieved to which rush orders and remakes can be
                      added real-time, without affecting the yield. DynOpt links the production batch-
                      es - which were formerly arranged by hand or semi-automatically - and the si-
                      multaneous cutting and breakout of several glass types.

                      Benefit

                      Definitions

                                                   everywhere.

                      Racks                        Labels are attached to racks too. You always know on

                      General
                      A+W Barcode Manager registers the production flow at essential points on the
                      shop floor, the so-called registration points. Registered data will be – directly
                      or indirectly – transferred to a collecting point and saved in the database.
                      The registration points are of central importance. They are identified by unique
                      number codes and are named.
                      A machine does not necessarily have to be a registration point. It can also be
                      subdivided into several registration points.
                      Example: IG Line
                      •   1611 > Machine entry,
                      •   1610 > the machine itself, and
                      •   1612 > Machine exit.
                      Splitting machines into several registration points allows detailed production
                      tracking and analysis.
                      Breakage registration is essential in this connection. Apart from the registra-
                      tion point and other information, the breakage reason is entered. Remakes
                      can be created automatically, depending on the configuration.


                      Scanners
                      Different scanner types are used for barcoding. Basically, there are online and
                      offline scanners.
                      •   Online scanners:
                          Online scanners include the line scanners and serial scanners which nor-
                          mally have no memory so that they have to transfer the scanned data di-
                          rectly to the connected system. If the connection fails, scanned data will be
                          lost.
                      •   Offline scanners:
                          Offline scanners like hand-held scanners or mobile scanners (e.g. Denso
                          scanners) have a memory which can temporarily save the scanned data
                          and transfers them to the system when connected to it.
                          Scanner selection is highly individual and depends on a variety of factors.
                          e.g.:
                      •   How many scanners with different logs shall be used?
                      •   Where shall the scanners be used?
                      •   Which radius do the scanner have to cover?
                      Apart from that there are other factors which will be discussed on site with a
                      member of the A+W team.
                      The illustration below shows the main stations on the shop floor where scan-
                      ners are used. Each station has its own name and registration point number:

                      The aim of the Production Terminals
                      The control station technique aims at:
                      •   Scheduled and optimized jobs or lots are distributed to the appropriate
                          workstations.
                      •   The work performed is booked.
                      •   Deviations from detailed scheduling are registered.
                      •   Scheduled and actual production processes are compared during produc-
                          tion.
                      •   The production process is visualized.
                      •   Remakes (due to breakage) are created automatically.
                      •   The workers at the machines are provided with all relevant information on
                          the lites (shape, alignment, sizes, processing).
                      •   The production process can be re-optimized manually.
                      •   The collected data are used for analyses.
                      Each of the production terminal modules provides special support for one of
                      these goals.

                      A+W Discovery
                      A+W Discovery is the new Business Intelligence System from A+W. This al-
                      lows evaluating and analyzing sales and complaint statistics, breakage, and
                      machinery times in a consistent environment, and possibly even for different
                      clients.
                      These precious data, especially in complex companies and groups of compa-
                      nies, are sometimes hard to get hold of. They are widely spread over different
                      sites and business areas, administration, sales, and production, different soft-
                      ware platforms, and modules.
                      A+W Discovery helps with the conversion, integration, and analysis of these
                      extensive, heterogeneous data. The program extracts data from multiple
                      sources, standardizes them, and units them in a common, homogeneous da-
                      tabase.
                      The modern OLAP technology permits fast and effective access to data as
                      well as complex calculations. Partial and end results can be easily displayed
                      by means of Microsoft® Excel® (Version 2010 and higher).
                      A+W provide a large number of basic reports for this purpose (display and
                      analyses) and allows to access different aspects of the data and view them
                      from different angles. This way, the Data Cube can link facts like target times
                      and actual times, costs, quantities, and turnover with dimensions like client,
                      customer, representative, production line, period, etc.
                      Automatic updating and processing of the Data-Cube on a nightly basis allows
                      up-to-date and fast evaluations.

                      Overview
                      The tutorial on the Rough Scheduling process addresses the batch creation in
                      A+W Production. With the different views in Rough Scheduling, the individuals
                      responsible for the production scheduling process obtain an overview and cre-
                      ate batches with different strategies that allow for an optimal production pro-
                      cess.

                         The functions depend on the enabled modules
                         Please note that the individual functions are available only if the corre-
                         sponding modules and interfaces have been installed and enabled.
                         If you detect functions in this description which are not available in your ver-
                         sion, please contact A+W Software GmbH.

                      Required knowledge
                      This tutorial is meant for persons in charge of production scheduling in A+W
                      Production who are responsible for organizing the optimum production pro-
                      cess. Participants must be familiar with the master data concept in A+W Pro-
                      duction.


                      Tutorial structure
                      This tutorial consists of sets of topics with several training modules in each.
                      Each module consists of the following elements:

                      Overview                   Each training module starts with an overview of the
                                                 major topics:
                                                 • Objectives: What shall be conveyed?
                                                 • Benefit: What can this knowledge be used for?
                                                 • Maxims: Which correlations are to be remembered?

                      Concepts                   First, the concepts and terms of the corresponding
                                                 training module will be explained. This is followed by
                                                 examples and instructions.

                      Exercises                  There are exercises featuring special tasks for some of
                                                 the training sessions.

                      Cross-references           At the end of each training module there is a section
                                                 with cross references pointing to additional information
                                                 in the software reference and in other sections.
                                                 This will help you to extend your newly acquired
                                                 knowledge.

                   The diagram above shows the production scheduling process including rough
                   scheduling. After scheduling from the ERP system, the orders and/or items are

                   the overview dialogs and you can apply strategies to create batches. If you

                      Rough Scheduling and Capacity Planning
                      Some functions of Rough Scheduling interact with Capacity Planning. The cor-
                      responding points are referred to in this tutorial.
                      Capacity Planning provides you with a direct access point to Rough Schedul-
                      ing; from within the Production Monitor you can open the Workplan dialog.
                      Here you can create and manage batches and order items by taking the re-
                      sults of capacity planning into account. With active capacity planning we there-
                      fore recommend to start the steps of production scheduling from within the
                      production monitor.

                      Set status
                      If you are working with capacity planning:
                      If you set the status or orders to produced, ready for shipment or delivered, ca-
                      pacity planning releases the capacities again. The respective functions are de-
                      scribed in the Capacity Planning Manual.

                      Terms in Rough Scheduling
                      The following terms are used in the description of Rough Scheduling.

                      Term                  Description

                      Orders / Pool         After the order data from the EPR system has been
                                            scheduled, the orders are listed in the Orders view which is
                                            also called Pool.

                      Pool_tables           The database tables Pool_ are filled with data during
                                            scheduling of the order data from the ERP system.
                                            Pool_tables describe the BOM and order header of a product.

                      Bill of materials     The BOM shows the elements that are included in an order in
                      (BOM)                 a tree structure. The BOM also describes the
                                            interdependencies of the items.

                      Item                  Items are parts of orders. An item includes different parts. e.g.
                                            float 4 mm and therm. 4 mm. The parts are subject to different
                                            kinds of processing, e.g. cutting or polishing.

                      Processing            Processing procedure with which the item is processed, e.g.
                                            polishing or grinding.

                      Work process          Work processes bring together the properties of processing,
                                            e.g. Polishing with the properties of the work piece. An item
                                            from the BOM, for example, includes the request to be
                                            polished in a certain way. Based on this request, the work
                                            process defines the special type of polishing.

                      Release parts         Parts that are explicitly to be planned for production. Release
                                            parts are shown in the views. Release parts are defined in the
                                            master data.

                      Non-release parts     Parts that are implicitly to be planned for production. Non-
                                            release parts are defined in the master data.

                                      For example, you can keep orders in a bucket until there are

                   Lot                Part of a batch that runs through the same production

                      White screen in a view
                      If a view does not display any orders and/or items, then either there are none
                      available or you have set the criteria of the view in a manner that no orders or
                      items meet the criteria. Examples of possible reasons for blank lists:
                      •   There is only one column in the view. A category has been defined for this
                          column that is not included in the orders.
                          For example, the column shows LAMI, but the orders do not include any
                          LAMI.
                          Remedy: Define a criterion in the column that corresponds to the orders.
                      •   There are several columns in the view. The criteria of the columns restrict
                          the orders so much that none are shown or the criteria are contradictory.
                          You have two columns, for example, one of which shows a LAMI and the
                          other one an IG. Orders that each only include LAMI or IG cannot meet both
                          criteria at the same time.
                          Remedy: Define criteria in the columns that correspond to the orders.
                      •   You have activated a filter, the criterion of which does not correspond to any
                          order.
                          For example, the list is blank if the filter only IG is activated and no IG is
                          included in the orders.
                          Remedy: Remove the filter or select a different one.
                      •   You have added a column that filters for batch-related information, for ex-
                          ample. If you have not yet created a batch for the displayed orders or items,
                          the column filters non-existing or unauthorized data and the result is a white
                          screen.
                          Remedy: Add columns for later work processes in production scheduling
                          only to those views that show later processes of production scheduling,
                          e.g. batch-related data in the batch view.

                      Batches are a grouping of orders and/or items that are to be processed togeth-

                         Rescheduling to other machines, machine allocation and capacity
                         planning
                         If you are working with capacity planning you must take the following into
                         account:
                         A new rescheduling to another machine or machine allocation from within
                         Rough Scheduling will affect capacity planning.
                         The respective functions are described in the Capacity Planning Manual.

                      Useful batches and batch strategies
                      The following applies in general: A batch strategy is good if it works. If you mix
                      different pane sizes into a batch, the yield is improved. Do not isolate special
                      products, but include special products in the batches.




A+W Production Rough Scheduling                                                                  C-139
Rough Scheduling                                                                              Tutorial




                   You can pursue the following batch strategies:
                   •   By glass type: You can create separate batches with thick glass panes.
                       Thick glasses are usually larger in size and thus result in a worse yield; it
                       may therefore be beneficial to create separate batches and produce thick
                       glass when it fits best into production.
                   •   By product type: In the case of more complex productions, e.g. IG, TG or
                       LAMI, it may be beneficial to compile product types in batches. You will get
                       a better overview of production and accept a lower yield.
                   •   By processing: You can compile orders or items to batches on a process-
                       ing-oriented basis, e.g. to minimize set-up costs and times.
                   •   By production date: Capacity planning assigns production dates to the in-
                       dividual processings. You can use those as a basis and create batches
                       from the respective processings with the same date.
                   •   By order and/or item: You can create batches from items or individual ele-
                       ments of orders. In the case of multi-step productions, this strategy will help
                       you to organize the individual departments. If you need space for changes
                       you can distribute different product types of an order to several batches.
                   •   Schedule in several stages: Here, you separate orders and/or items by
                       your main criteria and check the result. Depending on the yield, quantity,
                       residual plates and number of required racks, you separate parts into indi-
                       vidual batches and add parts to the batches.
                   •   Empty pool: With this strategy you pack new orders and/or items into buck-
                       ets or batches as fast as possible. The advantage of this strategy is that
                       you see new orders and/or items immediately when they are moved to the
                       pool. The disadvantage is that it is more difficult to keep track of existing
                       buckets and batches.
                   •   Full pool: You keep orders and/or items in the pool as long as possible. The
                       advantage of this strategy is that you completely keep track. The disadvan-
                       tage is that it is more difficult for you to notice new orders and/or items.

                       Careful with batch strategies
                       A+W Production gives you complete freedom in planning your production
                       and consequently full responsibility.
                       For example, you can ignore results of capacity planning.

                   You should not use the following batch strategies:
                   •   Using today's small sizes to increase today's yield. This strategy results in
                       problems on the following day.
                   •   Mixing too many products or glass types into the batches without appropri-
                       ate organization. This strategy results in an unclear production process and
                       jams.
                   •   Default glass quantity too small.
                   •   Delete batches to accept order modifications. It is better to move items or
                       batches back to the pool.
                   For details on how to work with batches, please see the following instructions:
                   •   “How to create a batch” on page C-141
                   •   “How to add orders to an existing batch” on page C-142
                   •   “How to manage batches or resolve batches” on page C-144

                   Rough Scheduling
                   In Rough Scheduling you create batches that you subsequently plan in detail
                   and optimize in the process of production preparation. The size and composi-
                   tion of the batch is decisive for the optimization results and production capacity
                   utilization.
                   After scheduling the orders, you will find them in the Orders dialog, also called
                   Pool. From here you are able to presort the orders into buckets or create
                   batches directly. The different views help you to obtain an overview of the or-
                   der data and details. From the views you create batches and transfer these to
                   the next process step in production scheduling: detailed scheduling.
                   You can adjust the views of Rough Scheduling to your demands so that they
                   show exactly the information that you require.

Notes on the Documentation                                                                          Tutorial




                       Notes on the Documentation
                       The tutorial on module Detailed Scheduling deals with the basics of the whole
                       production process. Starting from cutting, via the different production lines, up
                       to the transport racks. It is based on the knowledge of rough scheduling.

                             The functions depend on the released modules
                             Please note that the individual functions are available only if the corre-
                             sponding modules and interfaces have been installed and released.

                             If you detect functions in this description which are not available in your ver-
                             sion, please contact A+W Software GmbH.

                       Sets of Topics
                       The training on module Detailed Scheduling consists of the following sets of
                       topics:
                       •     Grouping and Sorting

                       Important Notes
                       This documentation is meant as an aid for the daily business and as a training

                       not meant for self-studies and cannot guarantee an operation which is com-
                       pletely free of errors because the complexity does not depend on the software
                       but rather on the real processes. Detailed scheduling defines the entire orga-
                       nization and production process within your production. According to your re-
                       quirements, it can be quite complex which is why it will be exclusively set up
                       by an experienced member of the A+W team, and installed together with you.
                       Should you want to change the settings please always contact A+W first to
                       avoid undesired effects!
                       The user has to be versed in the application of physical processes in glass pro-
                       duction and organization.

                        Detailed Scheduling - Over-
                        view
                        The glass required for production is usually cut from stockplates on the cutting
                        tables. Most companies have several, automatic cutting tables and at least
                        one cutting table for manual cutting or shapes.
                        After cutting, the lites are put onto racks depending on the next processing
                        step (e. g. A racks); the rack is then moved to the next processing station.
                        In a working area (e.g. cutting) or within a process chain (e.g. cutting > IG line),
                        dwelling and processing times can very considerably. Among other things, this
                        depends on the space available in this area for the racks onto which the lites
                        are put, on the complexity of the stacking logic, and on the distance to be cov-
                        ered in between steps. These are essential questions in terms of Detailed
                        scheduling. If there is only little space for the racks behind the cutting table,
                        this fact must be compensated by the appropriate optimization and the se-
                        quence of lites so that as few racks as possible are needed and only little ad-
                        ditional sorting is required.
                        For assembly on the IG line, the lites of a unit have to be stacked as closely
                        together as possible. They do not have to be put onto the same rack however.
                        This means that depending on the optimization, sorting may have to take place
                        before the line.




                           Optimization result
                           The optimization with the lowest waste is not always the chief target of
                           A+W Production. This is the case for instance if such an optimization re-
                           sults in an unreasonable amount of sorting work before assembly.




D-258                                                             A+W Production Detailed Scheduling
Tutorial                                                                 Detailed Scheduling - Overview




                       An important criterion for detailed scheduling results and the dwelling and pro-
                       cessing time is the size and composition of batches. Various aspects have to
                       be taken into account:
                       •   If a batch contains only a few lites, or only very large lites, there will be too
                           much waste. The stockplates cannot be cut to the best effect; the residue
                           plate will be too big.
                       •   If the batch is too big however, i.e. if it consists of a large number of lites,
                           the production time for this batch is extended and the racks will be occupied
                           for quite a long time. Racks can be used again only after the production of
                           this batch is completed.


                       The Process of A+W Production
                       Detailed scheduling begins just where rough scheduling ends. Rough sched-
                       uling results in batches. Batches contain elements to be produced. The task of
                       detailed scheduling is to determine a production sequence for the elements of
                       these batches.
                       The production sequence can be determined by criteria like:
                       •   customer's requirements,
                       •   results of packing optimization (PMO), or
                       •   production restrictions .
                       Detailed scheduling consists of various steps. All necessary processes (load-
                       ing data from the database, etc.) are processed in A+W Production in the
                       background, invisible for the user. The steps are based on each other:
                       •   In the first step, data are loaded from the database.
                       •   After this, detailed scheduling creates a bill of material based on the ele-
                           ments and the processing required.
                       •   After the bill of material was created, detailed scheduling allocates the ele-
                           ments to the available organizations and rack types.
                       •   Now, grouping and sorting takes place within the organization groups and
                           on the racks.
                       •   As a next step, detailed scheduling deals with putting the lites onto racks.
                       •   Next, production lots are created.
                       •   In the last step, detailed scheduling handles special elements (residue
                           plates, filler orders, breakage, etc.).
                       The primary products have to be put into a suitable sequence onto the racks
                       to produce the sequence required for the individual production steps. The rack
                       load after each production step results from the production sequence.
                       The following illustration shows the symbolic effects of the different settings in
                       A+W Production.

                        Lots
                        A lot is a number of lites which are used or produced on the same machines
                        and under the same conditions within a defined space of time. A lot contains
                        a number of lites of the same Lot type. In A+W Production, there are two lot
                        types:
                        •   Application lot
                        •   Production lot

                        Application lot
                        The lites of an application lot are necessary for producing the lites in the batch-
                        es. All lites of this lot have the same lot type.

                        Production lot
                        The lites of a production lot are produced in the corresponding batch. All lites
                        have the same lot type. Lites of a production lot are produced on the same ma-
                        chines. Lites destined for another machine are assigned to another lot of the
                        same type. Also, production lots can be separated by other criteria. It is possi-
                        ble for instance to split the production of IG units by spacer (AIR). This way,
                        several production lots would be created each of which contains only lites with
                        a certain spacer.


                        Additional information
                         Fig. D-2 on page D-263


                        Racks (storage locations)
                        Elements of a batch can be treated differently after they were cut. The ele-
                        ments are put onto racks (storage locations) for the next processing step. The
                        always belong to an application lot, i.e. they are necessary for production.
                        Therefore, they have to be put on the application racks in such a way that the
                        sequence can be maintained for the next processing step.
                        A+W Production distinguishes
                        •   Application rack
                        •   Production rack

                        Application rack
                        Elements of a batch can be treated in different ways after they have been cut.
                        The elements are put onto an application rack (storage location) for the next
                        processing step. The always belong to an application lot, i.e. they are neces-
                        sary for production. Therefore, they have to be put on the application racks in
                        such a way that the sequence can be maintained for the next processing step.
